path_1.title: 120 Beats Per Minute (2017)
path_1.feeling: Raw, urgent activism and queer solidarity hit me hard and kept me engaged.

path_1.title: Brave (2012)
path_1.feeling: Gorgeous and heartfelt, though the mother-daughter arc outshines the brisk fantasy plotting.

path_1.title: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1 (2014)
path_1.feeling: The propaganda and politics intrigue me, but the split-in-two pacing drags.

path_1.title: Melody Time (1948)
path_1.feeling: Charming snippets and tunes, but it’s a mixed bag that never fully sweeps me up.

path_1.title: Into the Woods (2014)
path_1.feeling: Clever, darkly playful musical with strong performances, even if the tonal shift loses a bit of magic.

path_1.title: Promising Young Woman (2020)
path_1.feeling: Bold, provocative and stylish, it left me rattled and impressed.

path_1.title: Beauty and the Beast (2017)
path_1.feeling: Nostalgic and pretty, yet too reverent to feel truly alive.

path_1.title: Exorcist, The (1973)
path_1.feeling: Still chilling and weighty, though I connect more with its dread than its shock.

path_1.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_1.feeling: Sweeping, wholesome and irresistibly tuneful—comfort cinema that warms me up.

path_1.title: Old Boy (2003)
path_1.feeling: Gripping and stylish, but its bleak cruelty keeps me at arm’s length.

path_1.title: Disney's Newsies the Broadway Musical (2017)
path_1.feeling: Infectious energy and rousing numbers, even if the stage capture lacks cinematic spark.

path_1.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_1.feeling: Ambitious and emotional, but the grandiosity sometimes mutes the intimacy I crave.

path_1.title: The Hateful Eight (2015)
path_1.feeling: Talky, tense and well-acted, but its nastiness wears me down.

path_1.title: Love, Simon (2018)
path_1.feeling: Sweet and affirming, if a bit too polished to fully knock me out.

path_1.title: Ma Rainey's Black Bottom (2020)
path_1.feeling: Electrifying performances and rich dialogue, though the stage roots show.

path_1.title: The Way He Looks (2014)
path_1.feeling: Tender, quiet and deeply sincere—I felt every shy heartbeat.

path_1.title: Paths of Glory (1957)
path_1.feeling: Powerful and principled, though its stark classicism keeps me a touch detached.

path_1.title: Breakfast Club, The (1985)
path_1.feeling: Earnest and empathetic, with moments that still feel spot-on despite some dated edges.

path_1.title: Before I Fall (2017)
path_1.feeling: Moody and thoughtful enough, even if the loop conceit grows repetitive.

path_1.title: Divergent (2014)
path_1.feeling: Glossy and watchable, but too derivative to spark much feeling.

path_1.title: Eighth Grade (2018)
path_1.feeling: Painfully authentic and empathetic—I cringed and cared the whole way.

path_1.title: Scooby-Doo (2002)
path_1.feeling: Goofy fun in spots, but the tone and humor wear thin for me.

path_1.title: The Hungover Games (2014)
path_1.feeling: Lazy, loud parody that mostly grated on me.

path_1.title: Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King, The (2003)
path_1.feeling: Grand, emotional and satisfying—even with the bloat, it swept me away.

path_1.title: Exorcist, The (1973)
path_1.feeling: Its atmosphere and faith crisis linger with me more than the shocks.

path_1.title: Beauty and the Beast (2017)
path_1.feeling: Pretty and faithful, but it never finds its own heartbeat.

path_1.title: A Very Murray Christmas (2015)
path_1.feeling: Cozy and slight—pleasant holiday vibes without much staying power.

path_2.title: 120 Beats Per Minute (2017)
path_2.feeling: Urgent, human, and heartbreaking—it pulsed with grief and defiance.

path_2.title: Brave (2012)
path_2.feeling: The mother–daughter bond warmed me even as the story felt familiar.

path_2.title: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1 (2014)
path_2.feeling: The propaganda chess intrigued me, but the split story left me unsatisfied.

path_2.title: Melody Time (1948)
path_2.feeling: Pleasant, toe-tapping vignettes that charmed more than moved me.

path_2.title: Into the Woods (2014)
path_2.feeling: Sharp songs, uneven tone—I admired it more than I loved it.

path_2.title: Promising Young Woman (2020)
path_2.feeling: Angry, stylish, and gutting

path_2.title: Beauty and the Beast (2017)
path_2.feeling: Lavish but hollow—pretty echoes instead of real magic.

path_2.title: Exorcist, The (1973)
path_2.feeling: Expert dread and faith tested—I respected it more than I feared it.

path_2.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_2.feeling: Big-hearted, rousing comfort that swept me along.

path_2.title: Old Boy (2003)
path_2.feeling: Operatic and devastating—hard to watch, harder to shake.

path_2.title: Disney's Newsies the Broadway Musical (2017)
path_2.feeling: Rousing tunes and empathy, though the filmed stage keeps me at arm’s length.

path_2.title: The Hateful Eight (2015)
path_2.feeling: Talky, mean-spirited chamber piece that kept me cold.

path_2.feeling: Sweet, affirming teen romance that made me smile.

path_2.feeling: Gentle and sincere, touching if a little slight.

path_2.feeling: Earnest and sharp, even if some edges feel dated.

path_5.feeling: Lavish and familiar, I enjoy the tunes more than I feel anything new.

path_5.title: Exorcist, The (1973)
path_5.feeling: Moody and unsettling, I admire its grip more than I am truly terrified.

path_5.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_5.feeling: Big-hearted, melodic comfort that genuinely moves me.

path_5.title: Old Boy (2003)
path_5.feeling: A stylish, twisted revenge spiral I admire at a distance, but the cruelty keeps me cool.

path_5.title: Disney's Newsies the Broadway Musical (2017)
path_5.feeling: Rousing, earnest labor song-and-dance that wins me over more with spirit than polish.

path_5.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_5.feeling: A grand, ideas-first odyssey whose heart hooks me even if the spectacle keeps me at a remove.

path_5.title: The Hateful Eight (2015)
path_5.feeling: A talky, chilly chamber western I admire more for craft than I feel.

path_5.title: Love, Simon (2018)
path_5.feeling: A sweet, affirming teen romance that warms me even if it is a bit glossy.

path_5.title: Ma Rainey's Black Bottom (2020)
path_5.feeling: A taut, soulful chamber piece whose ache and artistry linger.

path_5.title: The Way He Looks (2014)
path_5.feeling: A gentle, empathetic coming-of-age that genuinely moves me.

path_5.title: Paths of Glory (1957)
path_5.feeling: A searing, humane indictment that sticks with me.

path_5.title: Breakfast Club, The (1985)
path_5.feeling: An earnest detention confessional that warms me even if some edges feel dated.

path_5.title: Before I Fall (2017)
path_5.feeling: A moody teen time-loop that keeps me curious more than it moves me.

path_5.title: Divergent (2014)
path_5.feeling: Familiar faction-world thrills with little for me to feel.

path_5.title: Eighth Grade (2018)
path_5.feeling: A tender, cringe-honest adolescence portrait that quietly moves me.

path_5.title: Scooby-Doo (2002)
path_5.feeling: Goofy, candy-colored antics that amuse me more than they stick.

path_5.title: The Hungover Games (2014)
path_5.feeling: Strained, scattershot spoofing that leaves me mostly cold.

path_5.title: Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King, The (2003)
path_5.feeling: A sweeping, heartfelt culmination I admire and feel in parts, even if the spectacle keeps me at a remove.

path_5.title: Exorcist, The (1973)
path_5.feeling: Moody and unsettling, I admire its grip more than I am truly terrified.

path_5.title: Beauty and the Beast (2017)
path_5.feeling: Lavish and nostalgic, enjoyable tunes but little fresh feeling for me.

path_5.title: A Very Murray Christmas (2015)
path_5.feeling: A cozy, lightly amusing holiday hang that charms me more than it lingers.
